title: Install OO RAS on-premises
content:
Installing an external Operations Orchestration Remote Action Server (OO RAS) is optional. You may consider installing an external OO RAS for high availability.

Prerequisites

Before you begin, make sure you: 

  • Download and extract the installation package (installer-ras-<OS>-<latest_version>.zip) onto your local file system.
    Contact your administrator for the installation package, or download the installation package from the user interface of the product. 
  • Have an IdM user with a linked oo_topologyManage IdM permission. In IdM, the Permission/Role/Group/User association is as follows: 
    IdM Permissions are linked to an IdM role.
    An IdM Role is associated with an IdM group, a group may have multiple roles associated with it.
    An IdM Group is a collection of users.
    If you are installing OO RAS by connecting it to a SaaS OO, then contact the SaaS Support group to prepare the association with your username.
    If you are installing OO RAS by connecting it to your existing OO installation, then you can check in the IdM Admin console that the username (ie: your tenant admin user) has the required permission.
  • Know the ID of your tenant - OO RAS installation requires this tenant ID. 

Install OO RAS on Windows

  1. Extract the installer-ras-win-<version>.zip file. 
  2. Right-click on the extracted setup.exe and select Run as an administrator.  
  3. The Operations Orchestration Installation and Configuration Wizard opens. 
  4. Click Next.
  5. On the License screen, select I Agree, and click Next.
  6. On the next page, enter the installation path or use the default location and click Next.
  7. In the Location screen, select the installation root directory location.
    Valid characters for the installation path are English letters, digits, spaces, hyphens (-), and underscores (_).
    The default path is C:\Program Files\Micro Focus>\Operations Orchestration.
    If the directory doesn't exist, the directory gets created automatically. You are prompted to confirm the creation of the new location.

  8. In the Options screen, select the Remote Action Server (RAS) check box, and click Next.

  9. Configure the RAS Registration settings. Complete the following steps:

  10. In the RAS -> Central screen fill in the following fields with valid values:
    In the Central URL box, enter the OO Central URL location. Make sure to use the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) for the Central URL in the format: https://my.central.com:8443/oo/?tenantId=<tenantId>

  11. Under Central user capable of registering a RAS enter the appropriate credentials:
    Username (for LDAP users use the form of 'domain\user'): the user's name
    Password: the user's password. If relevant, add the LDAP domain using the following conventions: domain\user

  12. If required, select HTTP proxy definition for connecting to the Central (optional) and enter appropriate values in the text boxes:
    Hostname: hostname of your proxy server. For example, http://proxyserver.com.
    Port: port number of your proxy server. For example, 8080.
    Username: username of the proxy user.
    Password: password of the proxy user.

  13. Supply the CA root certificate of OO Central.
    If you are registering OO RAS on an OO Central hosted in SaaS, then this option isn't required, as the certificates used in the SaaS farms are already trusted by OO RAS.
    If you are registering OO RAS on an OO Central deployed in an environment outside of SaaS and:
    You are using a certificate signed by a trusted Authority for the OO URL -> this step isn't required.
    You are using a custom certificate for the OO URL -> you must supply either the CA root certificate or the certificate itself in a DER encoded form.

  14. Ignore the "Provide an X.509 client certificate" section.

  15. Click Test Connection.
    If the connection test is successful, continue.
    If the connection test isn't successful, review and change the settings. 

    The Python Executor will install on the default port for RAS (8002). If the port is already in use, when navigating to the RAS connectivity page, a new section with the Python Executor port will display allowing you to change the port with a valid one.
    Please note that after changing the port you need to click the Test Connection button again to validate the new port.

  16. Click Next. A summary of the installation displays.

  17. Review the settings and click Install.

  18. When the installation is complete, click Finish.

Silent install OO RAS on Windows 

This section describes how to perform a silent installation of an external OO RAS on Windows.

To install an External OO RAS in silent mode:

  1. Extract the External OO RAS installation zip package onto your local file system.

  2. Using a text editor, open the text file ras-sample-silent.properties which has the required installation and configuration settings.

  3. Save a copy of the text file as silent.properties.
  4. Remove the comment sign (#) from the properties you need, and add appropriate values for each of the properties.

  5. Open a command line prompt in the OO RAS installer's directory, and type the following example code: setup.exe -gm2 -s c:\\temp\my-silent.properties.
    To disable the extracting installation files progress bar, add to the command line -gm2 before -s.
    You can use the -n option if you don't want to start the External OO RAS after completing the installation.
    The -s property accepts either a full or relative path (relative to the location of the .exe file).
    For example, if dirA is the current directory, and dirB is under dirA and contains the installer and silent.properties file, open a Command Prompt window in dirA and enter the following command: dirB\\installer.exe -s silent.properties.
    You must add two backslashes (\\) and not one backslash (\). The installation folder's name where you download the installation file mustn't contain any spaces.

  6. Delete the my-silent.properties file.

Silent install OO RAS on Linux

This section describes how to perform a silent installation of an external OO RAS on Linux.

Only the silent installation option is available on Linux systems.

To install an External OO RAS in silent mode:

  1. After extracting the External OO RAS installation zip package onto your local file system.

  2. Using a text editor, open the text file ras-sample-silent.properties which has the required installation and configuration settings.

  3. Save a copy of the text file as silent.properties.
  4. Remove the comment sign (#) from the properties you need, and add appropriate values for each of the properties.

  5. Open a terminal in the directory where the OO RAS installer is, and type the following example code: installer-oo-ras-linux64-xxxx.xx.xx-MT.bin -s my-silent.properties.
    You can use the -n option if you don't want to start the External OO RAS after completing the installation.
    The -s property accepts a relative path (relative to the location of the directory where you launch the installer).

  6. Delete the my-silent.properties file.
The customer is encouraged to delete the <my-silent.properties>, which isn't provided. By not deleting the properties file you may be exposing the system to increased security risks. You understand and agree to assume all associated risks and hold OpenText harmless for the same. It remains at all times the Customer’s sole responsibility to assess its own regulatory and business requirements. OpenText doesn't represent or warrant that its products comply with any specific legal or regulatory standards applicable to Customer in conducting Customer's business.
The Python Executor will install on the default port for RAS (8002). If the port is already in use, the Python Executor service won't start and Python-based expressions will continue to be evaluated with the Python interpreter. To change the port for the Python Executor please follow the instructions on the Configure Python Executor page and restart the RAS service.

Import a certificate into the RAS TrustStore

After installing a RAS, reimport the OO certificate if it's renewed.

If you're using a custom root certificate for Central and you didn't include this root certificate during the RAS installation, you will need to import the trusted root certificate authority (CA) to the RAS client.truststore. If you are using a well-known root CA (such as Verisign) you don't have to perform the following procedure, because the certificate will already be in the client.truststore file.

By default, OO supports all self-signed certificates. However, in a production environment, it's recommended to change this default to a custom CA or a well-known CA for security reasons.

Replace the parameters that are highlighted in <yellow>.

The following procedure uses the Keytool utility that's located in <installation dir>/java/bin/keytool.

  1. Stop the RAS and back up the original client.truststore file, located in <installation dir>/ras/var/security/client.truststore.

  2. Open the command line in <installation dir>/ras/var/security.

  3. Open the <installation dir> ras/conf/ras-wrapper.conf file and make sure that the -Dssl.support-self-signed value is false. This enables the trusted root CA.

    For example: wrapper.java.additional.<x>=-Dssl.support-self-signed=false

  4. Open the <installation dir> ras/conf/ras-wrapper.conf file and make sure that the -Dssl.verifyHostName is true. This verifies that the FQDN in the certificate matches the FQDN of the request.
    This property is true by default.

    For example: wrapper.java.additional.<x>=-Dssl.verifyHostName=true

  5. Import the trusted root certificate authority (CA) to the RAS client.truststore file if it doesn't already exist in the CA list (by default, all the well-known CAs are there).
    If you haven't implemented a custom password the keystore/truststore uses the default Java password changeit.

    keytool -importcert -alias <any_alias> -keystore <path to the client.truststore> -file <certificate_name.extension> -storepass <changeit>
  6. Start the RAS.
